P048: I confess, said I, I am mistaken, I consider'd only the Situation of the Sun, without the Effects of its Light. But, pray, Madam, allow me to tell you, that you who have corrected me so justly, may also be mistaken your self: The Inhabitants of the Sun wou'd not so much as see it self; for they wou'd be incapable to support the dazling of his Light, or unable to receive it, by being too near; and all things well consider'd, the Sun wou'd be a Country of blind Men only. So that, once for all, I conclude, the Sun cannot be inhabited; and if you please, Madam, we will continue our Journey to the other Worlds: We are now come to the Centre, which is the lowest Point in all Circular Figures; and therefore must return back again, and go upwards. In the Way, we shall find Mercury, Venus, the Earth, and the Moon; all which Planets we have visited.

P049: The next that presents it self to our Observation is Mars, who contains nothing rare or curious that I know of: His Days are not a full Hour longer than ours, but his Years are double the length of ours. Mars is less than the Earth, and his Inhabitants see the Sun neither so big, nor so bright as we do. In short, Mars is not worthy the pains of a longer Discourse; but 'tis very curious to observe Iupiter, and his four Moons, or Guards: they are four little Planets, which turn round Iupiter, as our Moon turns round us. But, says the Marquiese, interrupting me, why are there some Planets attending upon others, who, it may be, are no better than themselves? In my Opinion, it wou'd be more regular and uniform if all the Planets, great and small, had but one Motion round the Sun. Ah, Madam! said I; if you understood the Tourbillions, or Whistlings of Monsieur Des Cartes, whose Name is so terrible, and Idea's so agreeable, you wou'd not talk at that rate. Let my Brains turn round, said she, laughing, if they will; I long to know what these Tourbillions are; make haste therefore to satisfie me, I'll manage my self no longer, but henceforth abandon all my Thoughts to Philosophy, without Reserve, let the World talk what they please; but let me understand these Whirling's. I did not think you capable of such Transports, said I, Madam; and I am sorry they have not a fitter Object: But to satisfie you, a Tourbillion is a heap of Matter, whose parts are disjoin'd one from another, yet moving round all one way; each little part being allow'd a particular Motion of its own, provided always they do not obstruct the general Circular Motion. As for Example; A Tourbillion of Air, call'd a Whirl-wind, or a Hurricain, is an infinite quantity of little Particles of Air, turning all round together, carrying along every thing they meet with in their way: You know that the Planets are carry'd round in the Celestial Matter, which is incredibly subtile and swift; all that vast Ocean, and Mass of Celestial Substance, which is between the Sun, and the Sphere of the fixed Stars, turns round, and carries with it the Planets one way, from East to West, round the Sun, which is plac'd in the Centre; but in shorter or longer time, as they are distant or nearer the Centre, all things turn round, even the Sun it self; but he turns round upon his own Axis: And you are to observe thus; if the Earth were in the middle of the Celestial Matter, as the Sun is, she wou'd also turn round upon her own Axis, like that: This is that great Tourbillion, of which the Sun is, as it were, Governor; but at the same time, all the Planets have little Whirlings peculiar to themselves, in imitation of that great one, the Sun; notwithstanding, they are all carry'd round the Sun, yet every one of them turns round upon his own Axis, and sweeps along with him a share of the Celestial Substance, which yields easily to any Impulse of Motion it receives, provided that does not obstruct its general Motion round the Sun; and this is call'd the particular Whirling, or Tourbillion of a Planet, which extends as far as the Sphere of its Activity can reach; and if it falls so out, that any lesser Planet than that which governs the Tourbillion comes in its way, 'tis carry'd with it, and indispensably forc'd round it; but yet that does not hinder both the greater Planet, and the lesser, with their Whirlings, to turn round with the great Tourbillion of the Sun. 'Twas thus that, after the Creation of the Universe, the Earth carry'd the Moon round it self, because the Moon fell within the Extent or Sphere of Activity, and forc'd its Obedience. Iupiter, of whom I have said somewhat already, was happier or stronger than we; there fell four little Planets in his Neighbourhood, and he subdu'd 'em all four: Our Earth, which is now a chief Planet, had it fallen within the Tourbillion of Iupiter, you may easily believe he wou'd have forc'd us to have turn'd round him also, Iupiter being ninety times bigger than our Earth; and then we had been nothing but a Moon depending upon Iupiter, whereas now the Earth has a Moon of her own turning round her: So true it is, that Chance of Situation has decided our Fortune. Pray, what Assurance have we, said the Marquiese, that our Earth shall always remain in the same Situation? I am afraid we may make a Trip one Day or other, towards some Planet as dangerous as Iupiter, who may sweep us round with it self; or that some other stronger Planet may approach nearer to us; for I fansie, that the violent Motions of the heavenly Matter you speak of, may agitate and shake the Planets so irregularly, that it might sometimes bring 'em nearer together, and at other times remove 'em farther from one another. We might gain rather than lose by that Bargain, said I; for it may be, our Earth wou'd be carry'd near Venus and Mercury, which are little Planets, and cou'd not resist ours: But we have nothing either to hope or fear from such an Accident; the Planets must remain where they are, new Conquests are forbid them, as they were heretofore to the Kings of China. You know very well, when one mixes Oil and Water together in a Vessel, the Oil will swim above; and if you throw any very light thing into the Vessel, the Oil will support it, and it will not penetrate into the Water: Throw in any other thing, somewhat heavier, of a proportionable weight to penetrate the Oil, which is too weak to stop it; 'twill fall upon the Water, and swim, the Water being sufficiently strong to bear it up. So that this Vessel, full of two Liquors, which does not mingle together two Bodies of an unequal weight, rests naturally in two different Positions, the one above the other; so as the lightest can never descend, the heaviest can never ascend. If you add other Liquors that will not mingle together, and throw as many Bodies into 'em of proportionable weight, 'twill still be the same thing. Imagine to your self, that the Celestial Substance which fills the vast Tourbillion, or Whirling of the Sun, is compos'd of different Coats, wrapp'd within one another, like an Onion; these Coats are of different weights and force, as Oil and Water, and other Liquors. The Planets also are of different weights; and by consequence, every one of the Planets must stop upon that Coat proportionable to its weight, and which has necessary strength for supporting it, and keeping it in an equal Balance; and you will perceive it is not possible in Nature they can remove from thence.

explanations: The French 'Encore un coup' (literally 'once again' or 'one more time'), used here to signal a concluding thought, is translated as 'So that, once for all, I conclude', which explicitly spells out the conclusive function of the phrase.

The French 'tout ce qui est rond' (everything that is round) is made more specific in English as 'all Circular Figures', explicitly linking the roundness to geometric or astronomical figures relevant to the discussion.

The French 'se presente' (presents itself) referring to Mars is translated as 'presents it self to our Observation'. The addition 'to our Observation' explicitly clarifies the context in which Mars is being considered, i.e., as an object of their scientific discussion and observation.

The French 'il voit le Soleil' (it [Mars] sees the Sun, or one sees the Sun from it) is translated as 'his Inhabitants see the Sun'. This makes explicit *who* is doing the seeing from Mars, aligning with the book's theme of extraterrestrial life and popularizing the idea of planetary inhabitants.

The French 'Lunes ou Satellites' (Moons or Satellites) is translated as 'Moons, or Guards'. While 'satellite' derives from Latin for attendant/guard, the English 'Guards' makes this specific relational aspect (of Jupiter's moons to Jupiter) more vivid and explicit for a general reader than the potentially more abstract or purely technical 'Satellites'.

The French 'Tourbillons' (whirlwinds/vortices) is translated as 'Tourbillions, or Whistlings'. The addition of 'or Whistlings' offers an alternative, more sensory (auditory) and perhaps more common-language term to help the reader grasp Descartes's concept, thereby explicitating one possible perceived characteristic of the phenomenon.

The Marquise's French exclamation 'Achevez de me rendre folle' (Finish driving me mad [with curiosity]) is rendered as 'make haste therefore to satisfie me'. This translation explicitly spells out her urgent desire for an explanation, which was an emotional implication in the source.

The French 'je ne connois plus de retenuë sur la Philosophie' (I no longer know any restraint regarding philosophy) is expanded to 'henceforth abandon all my Thoughts to Philosophy, without Reserve'. The English translation spells out more fully the manner and totality of her commitment to philosophical inquiry.

The French '& donnons-nous aux Tourbillons' (and let's give ourselves to the Tourbillons) is translated as 'but let me understand these Whirling's'. This makes explicit the Marquise's desire for comprehension ('let me understand') rather than just immersion, and re-uses the translator's explicitating term 'Whirling's'.

The French 'mouvement general' (general motion) of the tourbillon is translated as 'general Circular Motion'. The addition of 'Circular' explicitly defines the geometric nature of this motion, which is implied by the term 'tourbillon' but not stated in 'mouvement general'.

The French 'un Tourbillon de vent' (a whirlwind of wind) is translated as 'A Tourbillion of Air, call'd a Whirl-wind, or a Hurricain'. The translator adds common English equivalents 'Whirl-wind, or a Hurricain', making the scientific concept more explicit and readily understandable by linking it to familiar meteorological terms.

The French 'sont portées' (are carried), referring to the planets in the celestial matter, is translated as 'are carry'd round'. The addition of 'round' explicitly specifies the direction of this carrying motion, crucial to the vortex theory being explained.

The French 'd'une agitation prodigieuse' (of a prodigious agitation/movement), describing the celestial matter, is rendered by 'swift'. This specifies the *nature* of the 'agitation' as being rapid, making an implied characteristic explicit.

The French 'Etoiles fixes' (fixed Stars) is translated as 'Sphere of the fixed Stars'. The addition of 'Sphere' makes the prevailing cosmological model (where fixed stars were thought to be embedded in a celestial sphere) explicit for the reader.

The French 'en un même sens' (in the same direction) for the planets' motion around the Sun is translated as 'one way, from East to West'. This makes the 'same direction' more specific by providing a (then common, though complex in heliocentric context) astronomical directional reference.

The French 'sur luy-même' (on itself), referring to the Sun's rotation, is translated as 'upon his own Axis'. The addition of 'Axis' makes the type of rotation explicit using precise astronomical terminology.

The French 'elle ne pourroit encore faire moins que de tourner sur elle- même' (it [Earth] could still not do less than turn on itself) is translated as 'she wou'd also turn round upon her own Axis, like that'. 'Upon her own Axis' makes the rotation type explicit, and 'like that' spells out the implied comparison to the Sun's rotation.

The French 'celuy du Soleil' (that of the Sun), referring to the Sun's tourbillon, is translated as 'that great one, the Sun'. This explicitly names 'the Sun' and adds the descriptive 'that great one', enhancing clarity and emphasis.

The French 'qui est toûjours prête à suivre tous les mouvements qu'on luy veut donner' (which [celestial matter] is always ready to follow all the movements one wants to give it) is translated as 'which yields easily to any Impulse of Motion it receives'. This explains *how* the matter is ready to follow by detailing its responsive property, making the mechanism more explicit.

The French 'son mouvement general' (its general motion) regarding a planet's tourbillon is translated as 'its general Motion round the Sun'. Adding 'round the Sun' explicitly specifies the reference point and nature of this overarching movement.

The French 'la force de son mouvement se peut étendre' (the force of its movement can extend) describing a planet's tourbillon, is translated as 'the Sphere of its Activity can reach'. 'Sphere of Activity' is a more formal and specific term, explicitly defining the tourbillon's extent as a distinct region of influence.

The French 'celle qui y domine' (that which dominates there), referring to the main planet in a small tourbillon, is translated as 'that which governs the Tourbillion'. This provides a more explicit description of the dominant planet's role and function within its vortex system.

The French 'au commencement du Monde' (at the beginning of the World) is translated as 'after the Creation of the Universe'. This phrasing is more specific and grander, explicitly linking the event to a concept of universal creation, potentially resonating with contemporary scientific-theological discourse.

The French 'l'étenduë de notre Tourbillon' (the extent of our Tourbillon) is translated as 'the Extent or Sphere of Activity'. The term 'Sphere of Activity' is re-used to explicitly define this region of influence with a more scientific-sounding term.

The French phrase '& tout à fait à notre bienséance' (and entirely to our convenience/suitability), describing the Moon's relation to Earth's tourbillon, is translated as 'and forc'd its Obedience'. This makes the implied power dynamic explicit, reinterpreting 'bienséance' as a result of Earth's dominant force.

The French conditional 'si nous nous fussions trouvés proches de luy [Jupiter]' (if we had found ourselves near him) is translated as 'had it fallen within the Tourbillion of Iupiter'. This makes the nature of the proximity explicit by directly linking it to Descartes' vortex theory and the mechanism of capture.

The French rhetorical question 'croyez-vous que nous l'eussions êté [une Planète principale]' (do you believe we would have been it [a principal planet]?) is translated by explicitly stating the consequence: 'he wou'd have forc'd us to have turn'd round him also'. This spells out what the loss of principal status would entail.

The French 'pour nous absorber' (to absorb us), referring to Jupiter's potential action on Earth, is translated as 'who may sweep us round with it self'. This explains the *mechanism* of 'absorption' according to the vortex theory, making the process more explicit.

The French '& qui soit justement d'une certaine pesanteur' (and which is precisely of a certain heaviness), describing a body placed in oil/water, is translated as 'of a proportionable weight to penetrate the Oil'. This explicitly states the *functional characteristic* of this specific weight – its proportionality to the task of penetrating the oil layer.

The French 'deux Corps inégalement pesants se mettent naturellement à deux places differentes' (two unequally heavy bodies naturally place themselves in two different places) is translated regarding their final state as resting 'in two different Positions, the one above the other'. The addition 'the one above the other' explicitly describes the spatial relationship implied by different densities and the layering of liquids.

The French '& jamais l'un ne montera, ny l'autre ne descendra' (and never will one rise, nor the other descend) is clarified as 'so as the lightest can never descend, the heaviest can never ascend'. This explicitly assigns the behaviors (not descending, not ascending) to the correct type of body (lightest, heaviest).

The French 'qui se tiennent separées' (that keep themselves separate), describing different liquors, is translated as 'that will not mingle together'. This explicitly states the property of immiscibility as the reason for their separation.

The French 'qu'on y plonge d'autres corps' (and one plunges other bodies into them) is expanded to 'throw as many Bodies into 'em of proportionable weight'. The additions 'as many Bodies' and particularly 'of proportionable weight' make explicit the quantity and the crucial characteristic (appropriate weight for each layer) of these bodies, reinforcing the scientific principle being illustrated.

The French 'à differentes couches qui s'enveloppent les unes les autres' (has different layers that envelop one another) is translated as 'is compos'd of different Coats, wrapp'd within one another, like an Onion;'. The addition of the simile 'like an Onion' provides a concrete, everyday analogy to make the concept of nested layers explicit and more easily visualized.

The French 'dont les pesanteurs sont différentes' (whose heavinesses/weights are different), describing the layers of celestial matter, is translated as 'these Coats are of different weights and force'. The addition of 'and force' explicitly introduces the concept of force related to these layers, important for explaining how they support planets.

The French 'chacune d'elles par consequent s'arrête dans la couche qui a précisément la force necessaire pour la soûtenir' (each of them consequently stops in the layer that has precisely the necessary force to support it) is translated as 'every one of the Planets must stop upon that Coat proportionable to its weight'. The phrase 'proportionable to its weight' explicitly states the direct relationship between the planet's weight and the characteristic of the celestial layer it settles in.

The French 'il n'est pas possible qu'elle en sorte jamais' (it is not possible that it ever leaves it) is translated as 'it is not possible in Nature they can remove from thence'. The addition of 'in Nature' explicitly grounds this impossibility in the laws of Natural Philosophy, giving the statement a stronger scientific authority.

chunks.sourceHtml: P067: Je conçois, dit la Marquise, que ces pesanteurs-là reglent fort bien les rangs. Plût à Dieu qu'il y eût quelque chose de pareil qui les reglât parmi nous, & qui fixât les Gens dans les places qui leur sont naturellement convenables. Me voilà fort en repos du côté de Jupiter. Je suis bien aise qu'il nous laisse dans notre petit tourbillon avec notre Lune unique. Je suis bien-aise qu'il nous laisse dans notre petit Tourbillon avec notre Lune unique. Je suis d'humeur à me borner aisément, & je ne lui envie point les quatre qu'il a.
chunks.manualHtml: P050: I understand very well, said the Marquiese, how these different Weights are regulated, according to their several degrees: Wou'd to God, there were some such Order amongst us Mortals, to confine every Man to the Station that is fit for him. I am now no longer in fear of Iupiter; I am satisfy'd that he will leave us at ease in our own little Whirling, or Tourbillion; I am easily pleas'd, and do not envy Iupiter his four Moons.

explanations: The translator adds 'different' to 'Weights' (for 'ces pesanteurs-là') and 'according to their several degrees' to 'are regulated' (for 'reglent fort bien les rangs'). These additions make explicit an implied distinction and provide clarifying details about the mechanism of regulation not directly stated in the source.
The translator adds 'Mortals' to 'amongst us,' making explicit the human reference of 'nous' (us), which is implied in the French.

The French 'Me voilà fort en repos du côté de Jupiter' (I am now very much at ease/reassured about Jupiter) is rendered as 'I am now no longer in fear of Iupiter.' This explicitation re-writes the statement by making an inferred prior state of fear explicit, an emotion not directly stated in the source's 'en repos.'

The translator adds 'Whirling, or' to 'Tourbillion,' providing an explanatory English equivalent for the French scientific term 'tourbillon' (vortex/whirlwind in Cartesian cosmology), thus making its meaning explicit for the target reader.

The translator adds 'Moons' to 'his four,' making explicit that 'les quatre qu'il a' (the four he has) refers to Jupiter's moons, information understood from context in the source but spelled out in the target.

chunks.sourceHtml:
P068: Vous auriez tort de les luy envier, repris-je, il n'en a point plus qu'il ne luy en faut. Dans l'éloignement où il est du Soleil, les Lunes ne reçoivent & ne luy renvoient, qu'une lumière assez faible. Il est vray que comme il tourne sur luy- même en dix heures, & que ses nuits, qui par consequent n'en durent que cinq, sont fort courtes, quatre Lunes ne paroîtroient pas si necessaires, mail il y a autre chose à considerer. Icy sous les Pôles, on a six mois de jour, & six mois de nuit. C'est que les Pôles sont les deux extremitez de la Terre les plus éloignées des lieux où le Soleil donne à plomb, & sur lesquels il paroit faire sa course. La Lune ne tient, ou paroït tenir la même route à peu prés que le Soleil, & si les Habitans des Pôles voyent le Soleil pendant toute une moitié de sa course d'un an, & pendant toute l'autre moitié ne le voyent point, ils voyent aussi la Lune pendant toute une moitié de sa course d'un mois, c'est à dire, pendant quinze jours, & ils ne la voyent point pendant toute l'autre moitié. Les années. Les années de Jupiter en valent douze des nôtre, & il doit y avoir dans cette Planete deux extremitez opposées, où l'on ait des jours & des nuits de six ans. Des nuits de six ans sont bien longues, aussi est ce principalement pour elles que je crois que le quatre Lunes sont faites. Celle qui à l'egard de Jupiter est la plus élevée, fait son cercle autour de luy en dix-sept jours, la seconde en septe, la troisième en trois jours & demi, la quatrième en quarante-deux heures. Leurs courses êtant coupées justement par la moitié pour ces malheureux Pays qui ont six ans d nuit, il ne se peut passer vingt & heures, qu'on ne voye paroître au mois la derniere Lune. C'est quelque consolation pendant des tenebres d'une durée si ennuyeuse, mais quelque lieu que l'on habite dans Jupiter, ces quatre Lune vous y donnent les plus jolis Spectacles du monde. Tantôt elles se lèvent toutes quatre ensemble, & puis se separent selon l'inégalité de leur cours; tantôt elles sont toutes à leur Midy, rangées l'une au dessus de l'autre, tantôt on les voit toutes quatre sur l'Horizon à des distances égales; tantôt quand deux se levent, deux autres se couchent; sur tout j'aimerois à voir ce jeu perpétuel d'Eclipses qu'elles font, car il ne se passe point de jour qu'elles ne s'éclipsent les unes les autres, ou qu'elles n'éclipsent le Soleil, & assurément, les Eclipses s'êtant renduës si familières en ce Monde-là, elles y sont un sujet de divertissement, & non pas de frayeur, comme en celui-ci.

P069: Gens de nôtre Lune, me fait douter que Jupiter en ait beaucoup sur le Habitans de siennes, & jr croy qu'un des avantages ausquels ils puissent le plus raisonablement pretendre, c'est de leur faire peur. Par exemple, dans celle qui est la plus proche de luy, ils le voyent trois cents soixante fois plus gros que nôtre Lune ne nous paroît, car il la surpasse autant en grosseur. Il est, jr croy, beaucoup plus proche d'eux, qu'elle n'est de nous, sa grosseur en augmente encore. Ils fent comme des Colonies de Jupiter; qu'elles eussent receu de luy, s'il êtoit possible, leurs Loix & leurs Coûtumes; que par consequent elles luy redissent quelque sorte d'hommage, & ne regardassent la grande Planete qu'avec rêspect. Ne faudroit-il point aussi, luy dis-je, que les quatre Lunes en- voyassent de temps en temps des Députez dans Jupiter, pour luy prêter ferment de fidelité? Pour moy, je vous avoüe que le peu de superiorité que nous avons sur les Gens.
chunks.manualHtml: P051: You wou'd be to blame if you shou'd, said I; for he has no more than what is necessary for him; considering the great distance he is from the Sun, his Moons receive and reflect but a very faint Light. 'Tis true, that Iupiter turns upon his own Axis in the space of ten Hours, his Nights are but four Hours long; and being so short, one wou'd think he had no great need of four Moons: But you must consider, in our Earth, under the North and South Poles, there are six Months of Day, and six Months of Night; because the two Poles being the two Points of the Earth, remotest from those Countries and Places, upon which the Sun darts his beams directly, and over which, to our Apprehensions, he seems to perform his Course: The Moon holds, or appears to us to hold the same Road with the Sun: So that if the Inhabitants near the South and North Poles see the Sun during one half of his yearly Course, and then lose his Light during the other half, it must follow, that they see the Moon during one half of her monthly Revolution, and lose her during the other half; that is, for the space of fifteen Days. One of Iupiter's Years is twelve of ours, and there must be two opposite Poles in that Planet where there are Days and Nights of six Years long apiece. A Night of six Years long is very long, and I believe these four Moons were chiefly created for that reason: The highest of the four, as to Iupiter, performs its Course round him in seventeen Days, the second in seven Days, the third in three Days and an half, and the fourth in forty two Hours. These Revolutions being thus divided by equal halves in these unhappy Climates, where there are six Years of continued Night, one and twenty Hours cannot pass without their seeing appear, at least, the last of the four Moons; which is a very great satisfaction, during so long and irksome a Darkness: But upon whatever place of Iupiter you shou'd inhabit, these four Moons wou'd represent to your view one of the most agreeable Sights in Nature: Sometimes they rise all four together, then they separate according to the inequality of their Motions; sometimes they see 'em over their Heads, directly above one another; at other times they see 'em appear above their Horzion, at equal distances; at another time, two of the four are rising, when the other two are setting; but above all, I shou'd be pleas'd to see their constant Eclipsing one another, or the Sun; for there passes no Day, without one of the two; and since Eclipses are so familiar to that World, they must certainly be a Divertissement to them, whereas they fight the Inhabitants of our Earth.

explanations: The pronoun "il" (he/it), referring to Jupiter, is made explicit as "Iupiter." More significantly, the French "tourne sur luy-même" (turns on itself) implies rotation around an axis, and the translation makes this explicit by using the specific scientific term "Axis," clarifying the mechanism.

The French "Icy" (Here), used to introduce a comparison with Earth's polar phenomena, is translated as "in our Earth." This explicitly specifies the location as Earth, which was implied by the comparative context.
The French "les Pôles" (the Poles) is made more specific in the translation "the North and South Poles," explicitly naming both poles which are implied by the plural in the source.

The French "il paroit faire sa course" (it appears to make its course) indicates appearance. The translation "to our Apprehensions, he seems to perform his Course" explicitly adds the human observer's perspective ("to our Apprehensions"), clarifying whose perception it is.

The French "paroït tenir" (appears to hold), referring to the Moon's path, is translated as "appears to us to hold." The addition of "to us" explicitly specifies the observers as humans on Earth, clarifying the subjective viewpoint implied in "paroït."

The French "sa course d'un mois" (its/her course of a month) for the Moon's movement is translated as "her monthly Revolution." "Revolution" is a more specific astronomical term than the general "course" (path/run), explicitly identifying the nature of the Moon's movement as an orbital cycle.

The French "deux extremitez opposées" (two opposite extremities) of a planet is translated as "two opposite Poles." While "extremities" in an astronomical context implies poles, the translation uses the specific term "Poles," making the reference to the planet's rotational features explicit.

The French "sont faites" (are made/done) regarding Jupiter's moons is translated as "were chiefly created." The word "created" (and "chiefly" emphasizing purpose) makes explicit the idea of intentional design or a creator's hand, an idea that is only a possible, weaker implication in the more general "sont faites."

The French "Celle qui à l'egard de Jupiter est la plus élevée" (The one which with regard to Jupiter is the highest) refers to one of Jupiter's moons. The translation "The highest of the four, as to Iupiter" explicitly adds "of the four," spelling out the connection to the previously mentioned group of four moons, which was only anaphorically implied.

The French "Leurs courses" (Their courses/paths), referring to the moons' movements, is translated as "These Revolutions." "Revolutions" is a more specific astronomical term than "courses," explicitly identifying the nature of the moons' movements as orbital cycles.

The French "la derniere Lune" (the last Moon) is translated as "the last of the four Moons." The addition "of the four" explicitly links this moon to the previously discussed group of four, a connection that was implied.

The French "les plus jolis Spectacles du monde" (the prettiest Sights of the world/in the world) is translated as "one of the most agreeable Sights in Nature." Adding "in Nature" explicitly frames these spectacles within the realm of natural phenomena, a specific interpretation of the broader "du monde."

The French "l'inégalité de leur cours" (the inequality of their course/path) referring to the moons is translated as "the inequality of their Motions." "Motions" is a more specific term in celestial mechanics than the general "cours," making the scientific aspect of the moons' movements more explicit.

The French "elles sont toutes à leur Midy" (they are all at their Midday/zenith) describes the moons' celestial position. The translation "they see 'em over their Heads" makes explicit the observer's visual experience and perspective ("they see 'em," "over their Heads") implied by the astronomical term "Midy."

The French "ces malheureux Pays" (these unhappy Countries/Lands) is translated as "these unhappy Climates." "Climates" specifies that the nature of these regions, and the reason for their being "unhappy," is their extreme environmental conditions (long nights), making explicit what was contextually implied.

chunks.sourceHtml:
P070: Et vous ne manquerez pas, dit la Marquise, à faire habiter ces quatre Lunes, quoy que ce ne foient que de petites Planetes subalternes, destinées seulement à en éclairer une autre pendant ces nuits? N'en doutez nullement, répondis-je. Ces Planees n'en sont pas moins dignes d'être habitées pour avoir le malheur d'être asservies à tourner autour d'une autre plus importante.

P071: Je voudrais donc, reprit-elle, que les Habitans des quatre Lunes de Jupiter, fussont donc toûjours cette monstrueuse Planete sûspedüe sur leurs têtes à une distance assez petite. En verité, si les Gaulois craignaient anciennement que le ciel ne tombât sur eux, les Habitans de cette Lune auroient bien plus de sujet de craindre une chute de Jupiter. C'est peut-être là aussi la frayeur qu'ils ont, dit- elle, au lieu de celle des Eclipses, dont vous m'avez assurée qu'ils sont exempts, & qu'il faut bien remplacer par quelque autre sottise? Il le faut de necessité absolue, répondis-je. L'inventeur du troisième Système dont je vous parlois l'autre jour, le celebre Tycho Brahé, un des plus grands Astronomes qui furent jamais, n'avoit garde de craindre les Eclipses, comme le Vulgaire les craint, il passoit sa vie avec elles. Mais croiriez-vous bien ce qu'il craignoit en leur place? Si en sortant de son logis la premiere personne qu'il rencontroit êtoit une Vieille, si un Lievre traversoit son chemin, Tycho Brahé croyoit que la journée devoit être malheureuse, & retournoit promptement se renfermer chez luy, sans oser commencer la moindre chose.
chunks.manualHtml: P052: And you will not fail, I hope, says the Marquiese, to bestow Inhabitants upon these four Moons, though they be little, inferior Planets, and only made to enlighten the Inhabitants of a greater, during their long Nights. You need not doubt of it, said I, Madam; these four Planets are no less deserving of Inhabitants, because they are so unhappy as to be subject to, and turn round a more important Planet. I wou'd, says the Marquiese, have the Inhabitants of these four Moons to be Colonies of Iupiter, and receive their Laws and Manners from thence, and pay Homage and Respect to Iupiter, and not to look upon that great Planet, but with Veneration. And wou'd you not also, said I, have these four Moons to send Ambassadors, from time to time, to the Inhabitants of Iupiter, and swear Fealty to him? For my part, we having no Authority over the Inhabitants of our Moon, makes me think that Iupiter has no more over the Inhabitants of his four; and I believe, one of the Advantages he has most reason to brag of, is, that he frightens 'em. For Example; The Inhabitants of that Moon next to Iupiter, see him three hundred and sixty times bigger than our one Moon appeareth to us: And as I believe that little Moon to be much nearer to Iupiter than Ours is; so his greatness must be by that considerably augmented; and they must constantly see that monstrous Planet hanging over their Heads, at a very small distance. And if it be true, that the Gauls of old, apprehended the falling of the Heavens: The Inhabitants of that Moon have more Reason to fear the falling of Iupiter. It may be, said she, they have that fright, instead of that of the Eclipses, which you told me, they are free from; and which must be supply'd by some other piece of Folly. It must be so infallibly, said I, Madam, for the great inventer of the third System, of which I spoke to you the other Day, the Ticho-Brahe one of the greatest Astronomers that ever liv'd, was far from fearing Eclipses as the Vulgar do; but instead of that, he fear'd, if the first he met (as he went out of his House in the Morning) were old, or if a Hare happen'd to cross his way, he instantly return'd home, shut himself up, and did believe that day to be unlucky; nor wou'd he dare to attempt Business of the smallest Consequence.

explanations: The French "répondis-je." (I replied.) is translated as "said I, Madam;". The addition of "Madam" makes the form of address by the philosopher to the Marquise explicit. This introduces a specific marker of politeness or social standing into the dialogue that is not explicitly present in the French source text at this point, thus altering the directness of the original.

The French "à en éclairer une autre" (literally "to enlighten another one," referring to another planet) implies that the planet is illuminated, which would by extension benefit any inhabitants. The English translation "to enlighten the Inhabitants of a greater [planet]" makes this explicit by specifying that the direct beneficiaries of the enlightenment are "the Inhabitants" of the other planet, rather than just the planet itself. This clarifies the purpose of the light by focusing it on sentient beings, a nuance that was only implied.

The French sentence simply expresses the Marquise's wish for the inhabitants of Jupiter's moons to constantly see the large planet hanging over them. The English translation significantly expands upon this initial wish. The majority of the target text segment – specifically the detailed speculation about the moons being 'Colonies of Iupiter,' receiving 'Laws and Manners,' paying 'Homage and Respect,' sending 'Ambassadors,' and swearing 'Fealty,' as well as the philosopher's interjections and comparisons regarding authority – constitutes a substantial addition by the translator. This added material spells out complex political and social relationships and hierarchies between Jupiter and its lunar inhabitants, themes entirely absent and not implied in the concise French original, thereby re-writing the scope and nature of the Marquise's initial thought.

Similar to a previous instance, the French "répondis-je." (I replied.) is translated as "said I, Madam,". The translator again makes the form of address by the philosopher to the Marquise explicit, reinforcing a level of expressed formality or social convention in their dialogue that is not explicitly stated in the French source.

The French "en sortant de son logis" (on leaving his lodging/house) contextually implies the start of the day for Tycho Brahe's superstitious observation. The English translation adds the parenthetical phrase "(as he went out of his House in the Morning)", making this temporal context explicit and clarifying a detail about the timing of the event that was only implied in the source.

The French "la moindre chose." (the slightest thing.) uses the general term "chose" (thing). The English translation "Business of the smallest Consequence." makes this more specific. It explicitly frames Tycho Brahe's avoidance in terms of 'Business' or undertakings of some import, rather than any abstract 'thing.' This narrows the scope and clarifies the nature of his superstitious inaction by specifying the kind of activities he would avoid.

chunks.sourceHtml:
P072: Il ne seroit pas juste, reprit- elle, après que cet homme-là n'a pû se delivrer impunément de la, que les Habitans de cette Lune de Jupiter, dont nous parlions, en fussent quittes à meilleur marché. Nous ne leur ferons pas de quartier, ils subiront la Loy commune, & donneront dans quelque autre erreur, mais comme je ne me pique pas de la pouvoir deviner, éclaircissez-moy, je vous prie, une autre difficulté qui m'occupe depuis quelques moments. Si la Terre est si petite à l'égard de Jupiter, Jupiter nous voit-il? Je crains que nous ne luy soyons inconnus.

P073: De bonne foy, je croy que cela est, répondis-je. Il faudroit qu'il vît la Terre quatre-vingt-dix fois plus petite que nous ne le voyons. C'est trop peu, il ne la voit point. Voicy seulement ce que nous pouvons croire de meilleur pour nous. Il y aura dans Jupiter des Astronomes, qui aprés avoir bien pris de la peine à composer des Lunettes excellentes, aprés avoir choisy les plus belles Nuits pour observer, auront enfin découvert dans les Cieux une petite Planete qu'ils n'avoient jamais veüe. D'abord le Journal des Savants de ce Pays-là en parle; le Peuple de Jupiter, ou n'en entend point parler, ou n'en fait que rire. Les Philosophes dont cela détruit les opinions, forment le dessein de n'en rien croire, il n'y a que les Gens tres raisonnables qui en veulent bien douter. On observe encore, on revoit la petite Planete, on s'assure bien que ce n'est point une vision; on commence même à soupçonner qu'elle a un mouvement autour du Soleil; on trouve au bout de mille observations, que ce mouvement est d'une année; & enfin, grâce à toutes les peines que se donnent les Savats, on sait dans Jupiter que notre Terre est un Monde. Les Lurieux vont la voir au bout d'une Lunette, & la veüe à peine peut-elle encore l'attraper.
chunks.manualHtml: P053: It is not just, said the Marquiese, that since that great Man was not free from the Fear of Eclipses for nothing, that the Inhabitants of that little Moon, shou'd come off at an easier rate: Let us give 'em no Quarter, but force 'em to submit to the common Law of Nature, and oblige 'em to yield to some other Folly. But since I will not trouble my self to guess at this time, what that may be, pray solve me one difficulty, which my Fancy has just now suggested; if the Earth be so little, in respect of Iupiter; does the Inhabitants of Iupiter see our Earth? I am afraid we are altogether unknown to 'em. Really, I believe it to be so, said I, for the Inhabitants of Iupiter must see the Earth ninety times less than Iupiter appears to us; which is too small to be perceiv'd by them; and all we can imagine for our advantage, is, to suppose that there are Astronomers in Iupiter, who after having taken a great deal of Pains, and fitting excellent Telescopes; and having chosen a very clear Night for making the Observation, they at last discover in the Heavens a little Planet, they had never seen before; and streight they set it down in the Philosophical Transactions of that Country. The rest of the Inhabitants of Iupiter, either never hear of it, or laugh at it if they do; the Philosophers themselves whose Opinion that discovery destroys, resolve not to believe it; and there are but some very rational People, that will trouble themselves with the thoughts of it. These Astronomers make new Observations; they again look upon this little Planet, and they begin to be assur'd that it is no Fancy but a real thing; then they begin to conclude, this little Planet has a Motion round the Sun; and after a thousand Observations, they at last find out that this Motion or Revolution, is performed in a Years time. So that, thanks to these learned Men, the Inhabitants of Iupiter know our Earth is a Planet and a World: The Curious are earnest to look on it through a Telescope; tho 'tis so little, 'tis hardly discoverable.

explanations: The vague French pronoun 'de la' (from it/that) has its implied referent made explicit as 'from the Fear of Eclipses.' This explicitation, likely drawing from the broader dialogue's context concerning common superstitions which Fontenelle sought to dispel, makes a previously implied concept concrete for the reader, thus clarifying the Marquise's comparison.

The general French term 'la Loy commune' (the common law) is specified as 'the common Law of Nature.' The addition of 'of Nature' makes explicit that the law pertains to the workings of the natural world, a central theme in Fontenelle's popularization of natural philosophy.

The French pronoun 'le' in 'que nous ne le voyons' (than we see it) anaphorically refers to Jupiter. The translation 'than Iupiter appears to us' explicitly names Jupiter, clarifying the object of comparison for the reader.

'Le Journal des Savants,' a specific French scientific periodical, is translated as 'the Philosophical Transactions,' its prominent English contemporary from that period. This cultural substitution makes the type and status of the publication (a leading scientific journal) explicit and immediately recognizable to an English-speaking audience of the time.

The French 'mouvement' (movement/motion) in 'que ce mouvement est d'une année' (that this movement is of a year) is expanded in the translation to 'Motion or Revolution.' The addition of 'or Revolution' makes explicit the specific astronomical term for orbital movement, thereby enhancing scientific clarity.

The French 'notre Terre est un Monde.' (our Earth is a World.) uses 'Monde,' which contextually implies both a celestial body and a potentially inhabited realm. The translation 'our Earth is a Planet and a World:' makes this dual nature explicit by adding 'a Planet,' thereby clarifying its astronomical classification alongside its broader philosophical designation.

The French 'Lunette,' in the context of astronomical observation ('au bout d'une Lunette' - through/at the end of a 'Lunette'), is translated as 'Telescope.' While 'Lunette' can refer more broadly to optical glasses or spyglasses, 'Telescope' explicitly identifies the specific instrument for astronomical viewing, removing potential ambiguity and enhancing precision.

chunks.sourceHtml: P074: Si ce n'êtoit, dit la Marquise, qu'il n'est point trop agreable de savoir qu'on ne nous peut découvrir de dedans Jupiter qu'avec des Lunettes d'approche, je me représenterois avec plaisir ces Lunettes de Jupiter dressées vers nous, comme les nôtres le sont vers luy, & cette curiosité mutuelle avec laquelle les Planetes s'entre-considèrent & demandent l'une de l'autre, Quel monde est-ce là? Quelles gens l'habitent?
chunks.manualHtml: P054: If it were not, said the Marquiese, very disagreeable for me to believe, that our Earth is not to be perceiv'd by the Inhabitants of Iupiter, but by the help of a Telescope, I shou'd find an Infinite Pleasure in imagining, I shou'd see those Telescopes — pointing towards us; and ours from a mutual Curiosity are levell'd at them, whil'st those two Planets gravely considering one another, the Inhabitants of both ask at one and the same time, What World is that? What People are those?

What People are those?
explanations: The French "qu'on ne nous peut découvrir de dedans Jupiter" (literally "that one cannot discover us from within Jupiter") is translated as "that our Earth is not to be perceiv'd by the Inhabitants of Iupiter". The translator makes explicit: (1) that "nous" (us), referring to the interlocutors on Earth, corresponds to "our Earth" as the object of observation, and (2) that the general agent "on" (one/they) performing the action from Jupiter are "the Inhabitants of Iupiter". This clarifies who is observing and what is being observed in a way that is implied by the context and Fontenelle's overall theme but not directly stated in the French phrase.

The French "comme les nôtres le sont vers luy" (as ours are [aimed] towards it) describes the orientation of Earth's telescopes. The translation "and ours from a mutual Curiosity are levell'd at them" explicitly adds the motivation "from a mutual Curiosity" for this action. While "mutual curiosity" is mentioned immediately after in the French source text in relation to the planets considering each other (`& cette curiosité mutuelle avec laquelle les Planetes s'entre-considèrent`), the translator brings this motivation forward and directly links it to the act of aiming the telescopes, making an implied causal link explicit at this specific point in the sentence.

The French `demandent l'une de l'autre` (ask one another), whose grammatical subject is "les Planetes" from the preceding conjoined clause "les Planetes s'entre-considèrent &...", is translated as "the Inhabitants of both ask at one and the same time". The translator makes two explicitations: (1) The agent asking the questions is changed from the personified "les Planetes" (the Planets) to the more direct "the Inhabitants of both [planets]", explicitly naming the hypothetical beings central to the work's speculative theme. (2) The reciprocity and implied simultaneity of "demandent l'une de l'autre" is rendered with an explicit emphasis on simultaneous action through the phrase "at one and the same time".

chunks.sourceHtml: P075: Cela ne va pas si vite que vous pensez, ontainer">ontainer">répliquay-je. Quand on verroit nôtre Terre de dedans Jupiter, quand on l'y connoîtroit, nôtre Terre ce n'est pas nous; on n'a pas le moindre soupçon qu'elle puisse être habitée. Si quelqu'un vient à se l'imaginer, Dieu sait comme tout Jupiter se moque de luy. Peut-être même sommes-nous cause qu'on y a fait le procés à des Philosophes qui ont voulu soûtenir que nous êtions. Cependant je croirois plus volontiers que les Habitans de Jupiter sont assez occupez à faire des découvertes sur leur Planete, pour ne songer point du tout à nous. Elle est si grande, que s'ils navigent, assurément leurs Christophe Colombs ne sauroient manquer d'employ. Il faut que les Peuples de ce Monde-là ne connoissent pas seulement de réputation la centiéme partie des autres Peuples, au lieu que dans Mercure, qui est fort petit, ils sont tous voisins les uns des autres, ils vivent familierement ensemble, & ne comptent que pour une promenade de faire le tour de leur Monde. Si on ne nous voit point dans Jupiter, vous jugez bien qu'on y voit encore moins Venus & Mercure, qui sont des Mondes, & plus petits, & plus éloignez de luy. En récompense ses Habitans voyent Mars, & leurs quatre Lunes, & Saturne avec les siennes. Voilà assez de Planetes pour embarrasser ceux d'entre eux qui sont Astronomes; la Nature a eu la bonté de leur cacher ce qui en reste dans l'Univers.
chunks.manualHtml: P055: Don't go so fast, Madam, said I; suppose, the Inhabitants of Iupiter, cou'd see our Earth; yet, they cou'd never see us, or so much as suspect our Earth to be inhabited; or if any Body were Fool enough to imagine it, God knows, how he wou'd be laugh'd at and ridicul'd by the rest of the Inhabitants. And it may be, we are the Cause, that some Philosophers in that World have been sued and persecuted for this Opinion: However, I believe, that the Inhabitants of Iupiter are employed enough in the discovery of their own Planet, without troubling themselves with the thoughts of us. And had Christopher Columbus been of that Country, and understanding Navigation so well, he cou'd not have wanted employment. And the People of that World know not the hundredth part of its own Inhabitants; whereas, in Mercury (which is a very little Planet) they are all Neighbours one to another, and converse familiarly together; and they esteem it, as but a Walk to go round their little World; and if the Inhabitants of Iupiter do not see us, you may easily judge, they can far less perceive Venus and Mercury, both which are more diminutive Worlds, and further distant from it than we: But in lieu of this, they see Mars, and there are four Moons, and Saturn with the five that belong to him. There are Planets enough, to perplex all the Astronomers there: And Nature has had the goodness to hide from 'em what remains of the Universe.

explanations: The addition of 'Madam' to 'said I' (for 'répliquay-je') explicitly identifies the Marquise as the addressee, information which is contextually understood in the French dialogue but is spelled out in the English, clarifying the direct address.

The French impersonal pronoun 'on' (one/they), subject of 'verroit' in 'Quand on verroit', is translated explicitly as 'the Inhabitants of Iupiter'. This specifies the agent as the population of Jupiter, which is more general in the French.

The French phrase 'nôtre Terre ce n'est pas nous' (our Earth, it is not us) presents an abstract distinction. The English translation 'they cou'd never see us' makes explicit the perceptual consequence of this distinction for hypothetical Jovian observers, spelling out an implied limitation.

The French 'tout Jupiter' (all Jupiter), referring to the collective reaction on the planet, is translated and clarified as 'the rest of the Inhabitants.' This explicitation specifies that the reaction comes from the population of Jupiter (not the planet itself as an entity) and adds precision by indicating 'the rest' (i.e., those not holding the foolish opinion).

The French 'se moque de luy' (mocks him / makes fun of him) is translated and expanded to 'he wou'd be laugh'd at and ridicul'd.' The addition of 'ridicul'd' spells out a more specific and severe form of mockery, making an implied aspect of the social consequence more explicit.

The French locative pronoun 'y' (there), in 'qu'on y a fait le procés', implicitly refers to Jupiter. The translation 'in that World' makes this location explicit, removing potential ambiguity and clearly stating where the philosophers are prosecuted.

The French phrase 'fait le procés à' (to put on trial / to prosecute) is translated and significantly expanded to 'sued and persecuted.' This explicitation spells out more severe and specific potential consequences ('persecuted') beyond the general legal process implied by the French, possibly to resonate with contemporary anxieties or historical examples of persecution for philosophical or scientific views.

The French relative clause 'qui ont voulu soûtenir que nous êtions' (who wanted to maintain that we existed/were), which describes the philosophers' stance, is summarized and reframed in the target text as 'for this Opinion:'. This explicitly identifies their belief as 'this Opinion' and directly presents it as the punishable cause, making the causal relationship more patent.

The French 'leurs Christophe Colombs' (their Christopher Columbuses), referring to generic explorer types on Jupiter, is re-written as a specific hypothetical scenario involving 'And had Christopher Columbus been of that Country, and understanding Navigation so well,'. The translation explicitly adds conditions of origin ('of that Country') and specific skill ('understanding Navigation so well'), articulating characteristics that were only implied by the archetypal name in the source and changing a general plural to a detailed singular example.

The French impersonal pronoun 'on' (one/they), subject of 'ne nous voit point' in 'Si on ne nous voit point', is again translated explicitly as 'the Inhabitants of Iupiter'. This reiterates the specification of the agent as the Jovian population, which is more general in the French.

The French possessive pronoun 'les siennes' (its own), referring to Saturn's moons in a general way ('Saturne avec les siennes'), is translated as 'the five that belong to him.' This makes the information explicit by adding the specific number 'five,' reflecting the contemporary astronomical knowledge of Saturn's moons (five were known by 1684). This introduces specific scientific data that Fontenelle chose to leave unstated or general.

chunks.sourceHtml: P076: Quoy, dit la Marquise, vous comptez cela pour une grâce? Sans doute, répondis-je. Il y a dans tout ce grand Tourbillon seize Planetes. La Nature qui veut nous épargner la peine d'étudier tous leurs mouvemens, ne nous en montre que sept, n'est-ce pas là une assez grande faveur? Mais nous, qui n'en sentons pas le prix, nous faisons si bien que nous attrapons les neuf autres qui avoient êté cachées; aussi en sommes-nous punis par les grands travaux que l'Astronomie demande presentement.
chunks.manualHtml: P056: What, said the Lady Marquiese, do you look upon that as a Favour? Without doubt, said I, Madam, there is in this great Tourbillion or whirling of the Sun, Sixteen Planets. And Nature, who is willing to save us the labour of studying all their Motions, has discover'd to us only seven of them; and is not that a great Favour. But we who are not sensible of this Grace, have so ordered the matter that by our Endeavours we have found out the other nine, which Nature had conceal'd from us, and we are sufficiently punish'd for it, by the great Pains and Labour, which is at present requisite for the Study of Astronomy.

explanations: The French "la Marquise" identifies the character by her noble title. The English translation adds "Lady" before "Marquiese," making her aristocratic status and the formality of her title more explicit for an English readership, clarifying information about her social standing that was already implied.

The French "répondis-je" (I replied) is a simple reporting clause. The English translation "said I, Madam" incorporates the direct address "Madam," making explicit the philosopher's polite and formal deference to the Marquise, a nuance implied by the social context in the original.

The French "ce grand Tourbillon" (this great Vortex) refers to a key concept in Cartesian cosmology. The English translation "this great Tourbillion or whirling of the Sun" explicates this by providing a synonym ("whirling") for the potentially obscure term "Tourbillion" and specifying that it refers to the vortex "of the Sun," thus adding clarifying information about the scientific idea being discussed.

The French "nous attrapons les neuf autres" (literally "we catch the other nine," meaning "we find/discover") implies human effort in the act of discovery. The English translation "by our Endeavours we have found out the other nine" makes this implied effort explicit by adding the phrase "by our Endeavours," thereby spelling out the means or manner of the discovery.

The French "que l'Astronomie demande presentement" (that Astronomy presently demands) indicates that the field requires effort. The English translation "which is at present requisite for the Study of Astronomy" makes explicit that this requirement is specifically "for the Study of Astronomy," thus clarifying the nature of astronomy's demands which was more general in the source.

chunks.sourceHtml: P077: Je voy, reprit-elle, par ce nombre de seize Planetes qu'il faut que Saturne ait cinq Lunes. Il les a aussi, répliquay-je, & de ces cinq Lunes, il y en a deux bien fraîchement découvertes; mais il ya a quelque chose qui est encore bien plus remarquable. Comme son année est de trente des nôtres, & que par consequent il a des Pays, où une seule nuit dure quinze ans entiers, devinez ce que la Nature a inventé pour éclaires des nuits si affreuses. Elle ne s'est pas contentée de donner cinq Lunes à Saturne, elle a mis autour de luy un grand Cercle, ou un grand Anneau qui l'environne entierement, & qui êtant assez élevé pour être hors de l'ombre du Corps de cette Planete, refléchit perpetuellement la lumiere du Soleil dans les lieux qui ne le voyent point.
chunks.manualHtml: P057: I see, answer'd she, by the number of sixteen Planets, that Saturn must have five Moons. He has so, said I, Madam, and two of the five are discover'd very lately, but there is yet something more remarkable in that Planet; for his Year is as long as thirty of ours; and consequently there are Climates in that World [translates "des Pays", where one Night lasts for fifteen Years together. Can you guess what Nature has intended for the enlightning of Nights so long and dreadful? She was not satisfied to bestow on Saturn five Moons; but has also given him a great Circle or Ring, which environs him entirely, and which is elevated sufficiently high enough to be out of the shadow of this Planet. It reflects the Light of the Sun perpetually upon the Inhabitants of Saturn, who have the Misfortune to live in that Climate, that is, so long a time depriv'd of the influence of his Beams.

explanations: The French "répliquay-je" (I replied) is rendered as "said I, Madam,". The addition of "Madam" makes the direct address to the Marquise explicit within this specific utterance, clarifying the formal social relationship between the speakers which, while understood from the dialogue's setup, is not explicitly marked in the French verb phrase itself.

The French phrase "quelque chose qui est encore bien plus remarquable" (something even more remarkable) is translated such that the English counterpart is "something more remarkable in that Planet". The addition of "in that Planet" explicitly specifies that the "something remarkable" pertains to Saturn, the planet under discussion. This information was only contextually implied in the French.

The French "des Pays" (literally 'countries' or 'regions') is translated as "Climates in that World." The addition of "in that World" explicitly clarifies that these regions are located on Saturn (the "World" being discussed). Furthermore, the choice of "Climates" instead of a more literal equivalent like "regions" or "lands" serves to specify the nature of these "Pays" in direct relation to the astronomical conditions (long nights) being described, making an implied characteristic explicit.

The French phrase "dans les lieux qui ne le voyent point." (in the places that do not see it [the Sun]) is significantly expanded in the translation. The English version makes several implicit elements explicit: it specifies that the light is reflected "upon the Inhabitants of Saturn" (who were implied beneficiaries); it adds an interpretive characterization of their situation, "who have the Misfortune to live in that Climate," derived from the previously mentioned "dreadful nights"; and it spells out the reason for not seeing the sun, "that is, so long a time depriv'd of the influence of his Beams," directly connecting it to the long nights on Saturn.

chunks.sourceHtml: P078: En verité, dit la Marquise, de l'air d'une personne qui rentroit en elle-même avec étonnement, tout cela est d'un grand ordre; il paroît bien que la Nature a eu en veüe les besoins de quelques Etres vivans, & que la distribution des Lunes n'a pas êté faite au hazard. Il n'en est tombé en partage qu'aux Planetes éloignées du Soleil, à la Terre, à Jupiter, à Saturne, car ce n'êtoit pas la peine d'en donner à Vénus & à Mercure, qui ne reçoivent que trop de lumiere, dont les nuits sont fort courtes, & qui les comptent apparemment pour de plus grands bienfaits de la Nature que leurs jours mêmes. Mais attendez, il me semble que Mars, qui est encore plus éloigné du Soleil que la Terre, n'a point de Lune. On ne peut pas vous le dissimuler, répondis-je, il n'en a point, & il faut qu'il ait pour ses nuits des ressources que nous ne savons pas. Vous avez veu des Phosphores, de ces matières liquides ou seches, qui en recevant la lumiere du Soleil, s'en imbibent, & s'en penetrent, & ensuite jettent un assez grand éclat dans l'obscurité. Peut-être Mars a-t-il de grands Rochers fort élevés, qui sont des Phosphores naturels, & qui prennent pendant le jour une provision de lumière qu'ils rendent pendant la nuit. Vous ne sauriez rier que ce ne fût un Spectacle assez agreable, de voir tous ces Rochers s'allumer de toutes parts dé que le Soleil seroit couché, & faire sans aucun art des illuminations magnifiques. Vous savez encore qu'il y a en Amérique des Oiseaux qui sont si lumineux dans les tenebres, qu'on s'en peut servir pour lire. Que savons-nous si Mars n'a point un grand nombre de ces Oiseaux, qui dés que la nuit est venuë, se dispersent de tous côtés, & vont répandre un nouveau jour?
chunks.manualHtml: P058: Well, said the Marquiese, (with the Air of a Person return'd to herself from some great astonishment) all that you say is contriv'd with wonderful Order, and sure Nature has seen and provided for the necessity of some animate Beings; and that the distribution of these Moons, was not a work of Chance, since they are bestowed only upon these Planets, that are at a great distance from the Sun, the Earth, Iupiter and Saturn; for Venus and Mercury have no need on 'em; they enjoy but too much Light already; and their Nights are very short; and it may be the Inhabitants of this Planet esteem Night a greater benefit of Nature, than the Day it self. But hold, said Madam the Marquiese, it seems to me, that Mars, who is farther distant from the Sun than the Earth, ought to have a Moon too. I must confess, said I, Madam, he has none; but certainly, the Inhabitants of that Planet enjoy some other advantage, which supplies that defect. You have seen several bodies —, both liquid and dry, which draw in the Light of the Sun; and afterwards shine and cast a light in the dark. It may be, that there are — great Rocks very high; which are naturally of such a kind of Substance, as to receive great Provision of Light in the Day time from the Sun, which they restore in the Night; and if it be so, you cannot deny, but it must be a very pleasant Scene or Representation, to see all those Rocks from all Quarters begin to shine, as soon as the Sun is down, and make Magnificent Illuminations without Art or Expence. You know also that in America, there are certain Birds, which shine so in the dark; that one may read by their Light, as well as by that of a Candle; and who knows, but there are many of these Birds in the Planet Mars, which fly about and enlighten that World as soon as the Sun is set?

explanations: The French pronoun "cela" (that) in "tout cela" (all that) has an anaphoric reference that is contextually understood. The English translation "all that you say" makes the referent of "cela" (the philosopher's preceding discourse) explicit.

The French "la Nature a eu en veüe les besoins" (Nature had in view/mind the needs) implies consideration. The English "Nature has seen and provided for the necessity" makes explicit an action of 'providing for' those needs, which is an interpretation beyond merely 'having in view'.

The French relative pronoun "qui" (who), subject of "comptent" (esteem) in "qui les comptent apparemment...", implicitly refers to the inhabitants of Venus and Mercury. The English translation makes this implicit subject explicit by using the noun phrase "the Inhabitants of this Planet" as the subject of "esteem".

The French "Mais attendez," (But wait,) is a continuation of the Marquise's established speech. The English translation inserts the speech attribution "said Madam the Marquiese," making the speaker explicit again at this point, even though already known.

The French pronoun "il" (it) in "il faut qu'il ait pour ses nuits des ressources" refers to the planet Mars, suggesting the planet itself possesses resources. The English translation shifts the focus by stating "the Inhabitants of that Planet enjoy some other advantage," making explicit that the inhabitants are the beneficiaries of these resources.

The French "des ressources que nous ne savons pas." (resources that we do not know) is a general statement. The English translation adds the clause "which supplies that defect." to "some other advantage," making explicit the function of these resources – to compensate for Mars's lack of a moon ("that defect" refers to "he has none" mentioned prior), a purpose that was implied but not directly stated in the source.

The French "Phosphores naturels" (natural phosphors) is a relatively specific scientific term. The English translation "naturally of such a kind of Substance" clarifies this by explaining that these are substances inherently possessing phosphorescent qualities, thus making the nature of "natural phosphors" more explicit for a general reader.

The French "une provision de lumière" (a provision of light) is expanded in the English translation to "great Provision of Light in the Day time from the Sun". The addition of "great" intensifies the noun, and "from the Sun" makes the source of the light explicit in this specific context of Martian rocks, reinforcing a detail mentioned generally for phosphors in the previous sentence but not reiterated here.

The English translation prefaces the clause corresponding to the French "Vous ne sauriez rier..." with "and if it be so,". This addition makes explicit the conditional link to the preceding hypothesis about phosphorescent rocks on Mars. This link was implied in the French by context and the earlier use of "Peut-être" (Perhaps) but not overtly stated as a preface here.

The French "un Spectacle" (a spectacle, sight, show) is translated and expanded to "a Scene or Representation." The addition of "or Representation" offers an alternative or more specific term, clarifying and elaborating on the nature of the visual experience implied by "Spectacle."

The French "sans aucun art" (without any art/artifice) is translated as "without Art or Expence." The addition of "or Expence" makes explicit an associated characteristic of natural (artless) illuminations – that they would also be cost-free, an idea implied but not stated in the source.

The French "qu'on s'en peut servir pour lire." (that one can use them [the birds' light] to read) states the functional possibility. The English translation adds "as well as by that of a Candle," making explicit a comparison to a familiar standard of brightness, thereby clarifying the quality or sufficiency of the light for reading.

The French "vont répandre un nouveau jour?" (go to spread a new day/light?) implies that this light is spread over Mars, the subject of discussion. The English translation "enlighten that World" makes the location explicit by specifying "that World" (i.e., Mars).

chunks.sourceHtml:
P079: Je ne me contente, reprit-elle, ny de vos Rochers, ni de vos Oiseaux. Cela ne laisseroit pas d'être joly, mais puis que la Nature a donné tant de Lunes à Saturne & à Jupiter, c'est une marque qu'il faut des Lunes. J'eusse êté bien-aise que tous les Mondes éloignez du Soleil en eussent eu, si Mars ne nous fût point venu faire une exception desagreable. Ah! vraiment, répliquay-je, si vous vous mêliez de Philosophie plus que vous ne faites, il faudroit bien que vous vous accoûtumassiez à voir des exceptions dans les meilleurs Sistêmes. Il y a toûjours quelque chose qui y convient le plus juste du monde, & puis quelque chose aussi qu'on y fait convenir comme on peut, ou qu'on laisse-là, si on desespere d'en pouvoir venir à bout. Usons-en de même pour Mars, puis qu'il ne nous est point favorable, & ne parlons point de luy. Nous serions bien étonnez, si nous êtions dans Saturne, de voir sur nos têtes pendant la nuit ce grand Anneau qui iroit en forme de demiy Cercle d'un bout à l'autre de l'Horizon, & qui nous renvoyant la lumiere du Soleil feroit l'effet d'une Lune continuë. Et ne mettrons-nous point d'Habitans dans ce grand Anneau, interrompit-elle en riant? Quoy que je sois d'humeur, répondis-je, à en envoyer par tout assez hardiment, je vous avoüe que je n'oserois en mettre là, cet Anneau me paroît une Habitation trop irregulière. Pour les cinq petites Lunes, on ne peut pas se dispenser de les peupler. Si cependant l'Anneau n'êtoit, comme quelques-uns le soupçonnent, qu'un Cercle de Lunes qui se suivissent de fort prés, & eussent un mouvement égal, & que les cinq petites Lunes fussent trois échappées de ce grand Cercle, que de Mondes dans le Tourbillon de Saturne! Quoy qu'il en soit, avec le secours même de l'Anneau, les Gens de Saturne sont assez misérables. Il leur donne la lumiere, mais quelle lumiere, dans l'éloignement où il est du Soleil! Le Soleil même n'est pour eux qu'une petite Etoile blanche & pâle, qui n'a qu'un éclat & une chaleur bien foible, & si vous les mettiez dans nos Pays les plus froids, dans le Groënland, ou dans la Laponie, vous les verriez suër à grosses gouttes & expirer de chaud.

P080: Vous me donnez une idée de Saturne qui me gele, dit la Marquise, au lieu que tan tôt vous m'échauffiez en me parlant de Mercure. Il faut bien, répliquay-je, que les deux Mondes qui sont aux extrémitez de ce grand Tourbillon, soient opposées en toutes choses.

P081: Ainsi, reprit-elle, on est bien sage dans Saturne, car vous m'avez dit que tout le monde êtoit fou dans Mercure. Si on n'est pas bien sage dans Saturne, repris- je, du moins, selon toutes les apparences, on y est bien flegmatique. Ce sont Gens qui ne savent ce que c'est que de rire, qui prennent toûjours un jour pour répondre à la moindre question qu'on leur fait, & qui eussent trouvé Caton d'Utique trop badin & trop folâtre..
chunks.manualHtml: P059: Your Rocks, and your flying Birds, said the Marquiese, do not at all satisfie me. I confess such objects wou'd be very pretty; but since Nature has given so many Moons to Saturn and Iupiter; 'tis a sign, that they are absolutely necessary as well to Mars. I shou'd have been glad that all the Worlds distant from the Sun, cou'd have had their Moons; and that Mars might not have been so disagreeably excepted. Oh! Madam, said I, if you think it worth your pains to make any further Progress in Philosophy, you must accustom your self to such Exceptions; in the best Systems, there are always some things that agree exactly; but there are other things, that one must adjust as well as one can, or leave them as they are, if there be no hopes to overcome the difficulty: Let us do so if you please with Mars; and since he is not favourable to us, say no more of him. And tell me if it wou'd not be strangely surprizing, if we were in the World of Saturn, to see above our Heads in the Night that great Ring in the form of a Semi-Circle, going from opposite Points of the Horizon; and which reflecting the Light of the Sun upon us, wou'd have the effect of a continu'd Moon. And shall we place no Inhabitants upon that great Ring, said the Marquiese, laughing? I answer'd her, that (tho in the Humour I was in, I was enclin'd to put Inhabitants every where) I confess, I dare not set any upon so irregular a Habitation; but for the five little Moons, there is no dispensing with them, for they must have Inhabitants. But some do imagine, that this Ring or great Circle is compos'd of Moons join'd very near together, having all an equal Motion, and turning one way, and that the five little Moons I spoke of, had only escaped out of this great Ring; what an Infinity of Worlds are there then in the Tourbillion or whirlings of Saturn? and yet whatever is the Cause, the Inhabitants of Saturn are miserable enough, notwithstanding the Assistance of this great Ring. 'Tis true, it gives them Light, but what kind of Light? Sure a very feeble one at that great distance from the Sun, where she her self appears to 'em, but as a little pale Star, a very faint heat and Light, so that if you wou'd carry some of the Inhabitants of Saturn to our coldest Countries, as Green-Land, or Lap-Land, you wou'd see 'em all of a sweat, and melt away with heat. You give me an Idea of Saturn, said the Marquiese; that makes me shiver with cold; whereas before you warm'd me as much with the descriptions you gave me of Mercury. There is a Necessity, said I, that the two Worlds that are at the extremity of this great Tourbillion, must be contrary one to another in every thing. At that rate, said she, the Inhabitants of Saturn must be very wise; for you told me the Inhabitants of Mercury were down-right mad. If the People of Saturn, said I, be not wise, they are at least in all Appearance so, and are very flegmatick, they know not what it is to laugh; and who take a whole days time at least, to answer the most trifling Question: They wou'd have look'd upon the grave Cato the Censor, as too wild and youthful for their Conversation.
chunks.aiHtml: P059: Your Rocks, and your flying Birds, said the Marquiese, do not at all satisfie me. I confess such objects wou'd be very pretty; but since Nature has given so many Moons to Saturn and Iupiter; 'tis a sign, that they are absolutely necessary as well to Mars. I shou'd have been glad that all the Worlds distant from the Sun, cou'd have had their Moons; and that Mars might not have been so disagreeably excepted. Oh! Madam, said I, if you think it worth your pains to make any further Progress in Philosophy, you must accustom your self to such Exceptions; in the best Systems, there are always some things that agree exactly; but there are other things, that one must adjust as well as one can, or leave them as they are, if there be no hopes to overcome the difficulty: Let us do so if you please with Mars; and since he is not favourable to us, say no more of him.
